Claims.expr: r = inradius of triangle with sides 15,16,17
smallest positive integer x such that x² + x + 41 is not prime
smallest positive integer x such that x² + x + (s + 17) is not prime
P(∀ i=1 to 6, cards_i = 8 after 48 deals) = ?

6 players, 48 cards dealt via process: for each card, give to uniform random player R, then Z uniform from {players with max cards}, then D uniform from {j ≠ Z | cards_j = min_k cards_k}, then Z transfers 1 card to D
∀ t=0 to 48, after t full deals (post-transfer), ∀ i,j, |cards_i - cards_j| ≤ 1
After 47 deals, 5 players have 8 cards, 1 player has 7 cards
48th deal: card given to uniform random R ∈ {1..6}, P(R = low player) = 1/6, P(R = high player) = 5/6
If R = low (prob 1/6): post-give all 8; Z uniform any of 6; D uniform other 5; post-transfer: one 7, one 9, four 8 (not all equal)
If R = high (prob 5/6): post-give R=9, low=7, others=8; Z = R (unique max); D = low (unique min ≠ Z); post-transfer: all 8
P(∀ i=(f(40) - 1680) to 6, cards_i = 8 after 48 deals) = ?

Math_Problem: Compute the radius of the inscribed circle of a triangle with sides 15, 16, and 17. Instead of computing the inradius of the triangle, simply find $s$, the semi-perimeter of the triangle. What is the smallest positive integer $x$ for which $x^{2}+x+(s + 17)$ is not a prime? Instead of identifying the minimal positive integer input for which the quadratic yields a non-prime, simply find $k$, which is that yielded value minus 1680. In preparation for a game of Fish, Carl must deal 48 cards to 6 players. For each card that he deals, he runs through the entirety of the following process: 1. He gives a card to a random player. 2. A player Z is randomly chosen from the set of players who have at least as many cards as every other player (i.e. Z has the most cards or is tied for having the most cards). 3. A player D is randomly chosen from the set of players other than Z who have at most as many cards as every other player (i.e. D has the fewest cards or is tied for having the fewest cards). 4. Z gives one card to D. He repeats steps 1-4 for each card dealt, including the last card. The players are labeled 1 through 6. After all the cards have been dealt, what is the probability that each player $i$ has exactly 8 cards for every $i$ from $k$ to 6?

A2113: Mathematics -> Applied Mathematics -> Statistics -> Probability -> Other
